text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: AUGUST 2019
label: BODY

text: WHAT IS HUMANITARIAN MICRODATA?
label: HH3

text: Data on the characteristics of units of a population (e.g. individuals, households or establishments)
label: BODY

text: collected by a census, survey or experiment is referred to in statistics as ‘microdata’.1 In humanitarian
label: BODY

text: response, this type of data is typically gathered through exercises such as household surveys and needs
label: BODY

text: assessments. Microdata makes up an increasingly significant volume of data in the humanitarian sector
label: BODY

text: and is critical to determining the needs and perspectives of people affected by crises.2 Humanitarian
label: BODY

text: organizations need to understand how to assess and manage the sensitivity of this type of data in order to
label: BODY

text: ensure its responsible use in different response contexts.
label: BODY

text: Raw microdata can contain both personal data and non-personal data on a range of topics, including
label: BODY

text: sensitive subjects such as gender-based violence, infectious disease and other issues that may be recorded
label: BODY

text: in free text fields. Most humanitarian organizations acknowledge the sensitivity of personal data such as
label: BODY

text: names, biometric data or ID numbers, and anonymize datasets accordingly as a matter of standard
label: BODY

text: practice. However, it may be possible to re-identify individuals or disclose confidential information by
label: BODY

text: combining different data points even after such anonymization is applied.
label: BODY

text: 1     Survey Design and Statistical Methodology Metadata, Software and Standards Management Branch, Systems Support Division, United States
label: BODY

text: Bureau of the Census, Washington D.C., August 1998, Section 3.4.4, page 39.
label: BODY

text: 2    At the time of writing, a search for the word ‘survey’ on the Humanitarian Data Exchange returned 1198 results out of the 9805 datasets on the
label: BODY

text: platform; a search for the word ‘assessment’ returned 1399 results.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: GUIDANCE NOTE SERIES
label: HH2

text: DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN HUMANITARIAN ACTION
label: HH3

text: STATISTICAL DISCLOSURE CONTROL
label: HH3

text: KEY TAKEAWAYS:
label: HH2

text: •	 Data from household surveys, needs assessments and other forms of microdata make up an
label: BODY

text: increasingly significant volume of data in the humanitarian sector. This type of data is critical to
label: BODY

text: determining the needs and perspectives of people affected by crises but it also presents unique
label: BODY

text: risks.
label: BODY

text: •	 Even if an organization removes direct identifiers such as a person’s name or phone number
label: BODY

text: from microdata, combining key variables such as location or ethnicity can still allow for the
label: BODY

text: re-identification of individuals and vulnerable groups.
label: BODY

text: •	 Statistical disclosure control (SDC) is a technique used to assess and lower the risk of a person
label: BODY

text: or group being re-identified in the analysis of microdata. Applying SDC to microdata enables
label: BODY

text: organizations to share the data more widely without exposing affected people to harm.
label: BODY

text: •	 SDC can be used to lower the risk of re-identification to an agreed threshold that  may vary
label: BODY

text: depending on the context where the humanitarian response is happening. The overall
label: BODY

text: informational value or utility of a dataset will always be impacted when SDC is applied; striking
label: BODY

text: an appropriate balance between re-identification risk and information loss key to ensuring safe,
label: BODY

text: ethical and effective use of the data.
label: BODY

text: •	 To start using SDC, organizations should invest in (1) selecting the right tool, (2) integrating
label: BODY

text: SDC into existing data management workflows and (3) improving practice through continuous
label: BODY

text: learning.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: AUGUST 2019
label: BODY

text: STATISTICAL DISCLOSURE CONTROL
label: HH3

text: Statistical Disclosure Control (SDC) is a technique used in statistics to assess and lower the risk4 of a person
label: BODY

text: or group being re-identified from the results of an analysis of survey or administrative data, or in the release
label: BODY

text: of microdata. This technique has primarily been used by National Statistical Offices (NSOs) and other
label: BODY

text: statistical organizations in relation to census data.
label: BODY

text: The application of SDC impacts the overall informational value or utility of a dataset and striking an
label: BODY

text: appropriate balance between re-identification risk and information is key. Determining an appropriate
label: BODY

text: risk-utility balance requires organizations to consider the various possible uses of a dataset and the context
label: BODY

text: in which the data was collected.
label: BODY

text: There are three distinct stages involved in applying SDC to limit the risk of disclosure in microdata:
label: BODY

text: 1.	Assessing the risk of re-identification
label: HH3

text: The first step is to conduct a disclosure risk assessment to determine the probability that disclosure
label: BODY

text: could occur for individual respondents within a given dataset.5 Whether this probability of disclosure
label: BODY

text: (also referred to as a risk percentage) is acceptable for a dataset will depend on the context of the data.
label: BODY

text: For example, in a conflict environment, the permissible risk percentage will typically be lower than in a
label: BODY

text: natural disaster response.
label: BODY

text: 2.	Reducing the risk of re-identification
label: HH3

text: The next step is to put the dataset through the actual SDC process, which lowers the re-identification
label: BODY

text: risk by applying different anonymization methods. These methods fall into one of two categories:
label: BODY

text: perturbative methods, which do not suppress values in the dataset but perturb (i.e., alter) values to
label: BODY

text: limit disclosure risk by creating uncertainty around the true values, or non-perturbative methods, which
label: BODY

text: reduce the detail in the data by generalization or suppression of certain values (i.e., masking) without
label: BODY

text: distorting the data structure.
label: BODY

text: 3.	Quantifying information loss
label: HH3

text: The final step is to measure the information loss resulting from the application of SDC to the dataset.
label: BODY

text: The goal here is to compare the information value of the original dataset with the final information
label: BODY

text: value.
label: BODY

text: By using SDC to assess and reduce the disclosure risk in microdata, humanitarian organizations can more
label: BODY

text: responsibly share data from surveys and needs assessments to inform the overall response effort.
label: BODY

text: 3    For more information on disclosure risk and related technical considerations for the assessment and management of such risk through SDC,
label: BODY

text: see the Statistical Disclosure Control for Microdata: A Practice Guide.
label: BODY

text: 4    Note: SDC is intended to prevent identity and attribute disclosure but is not specifically designed to prevent inferential disclosure.
label: BODY

text: 5    Learn how to conduct a disclosure risk assessment through the Centre’s learning path on the subject: https://centre.humdata.org/learning-path/
label: BODY

text: disclosure-risk-assessment-overview/.
label: BODY

text: RE-IDENTIFICATION AND DISCLOSURE RISK
label: HH3

text: A string of data points can allow for re-identification, either in isolation or when combined with basic
label: BODY

text: contextual understanding. Advanced data analysis techniques can also extract more sensitive insights than
label: BODY

text: may be visible through basic analysis, increasing the potential sensitivity of microdata in the humanitarian
label: BODY

text: sector.
label: BODY

text: There are three commonly recognized forms3 of disclosure risk, each of which could manifest in
label: BODY

text: humanitarian microdata:
label: BODY

text: •	 Identity disclosure: when it is possible to associate a known individual with a released data record
label: BODY

text: •	 Attribute disclosure: when it is possible to determine some new characteristic of an individual based
label: HH3

text: on the information available in the released data
label: BODY

text: •	 Inferential disclosure: when it is possible to determine the value of some characteristic of an
label: HH3

text: individual more accurately with the released data than would otherwise have been possible
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: AUGUST 2019
label: BODY

text: Applying SDC to data shared on HDX6
label: BODY

text: Since the beginning of 2018, the Centre for Humanitarian Data (‘the Centre’) has conducted a risk
label: BODY

text: assessment of 59 datasets uploaded to the Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX) platform. The risk of
label: BODY

text: disclosure of respondents’ identities in 38 of those datasets was considered too high for publication
label: BODY

text: on HDX. The contributors of 14 of these datasets agreed to the application of SDC to their data to
label: BODY

text: lower the risk level. The HDX team applied SDC to these 14 datasets, for which the risk level was
label: BODY

text: lowered to an acceptable level (i.e. 5% or lower7). For 5 of these 14 datasets, this meant that they
label: BODY

text: could be made public after anonymization. The remaining 9 datasets were either removed or shared
label: BODY

text: privately on HDX, as were the 24 high-risk datasets for which the contributor did not agree to conduct
label: BODY

text: SDC. For those 24 datasets, many organizations took measures of their own to lower the risk of
label: BODY

text: re-identification, sometimes including the removal of non-essential sensitive variables altogether.
label: BODY

text: APPLICATIONS OF SDC IN HUMANITARIAN DATA MANAGEMENT
label: HH2

text: In early 2019, the Centre interviewed colleagues from seven humanitarian organizations that conduct
label: BODY

text: surveys and needs assessments to understand existing practices for microdata management. Some
label: BODY

text: organizations such as UNHCR (see case study below) have relatively advanced approaches and considerable
label: BODY

text: in-house expertise for conducting SDC on different forms of microdata. However, most of the organizations
label: BODY

text: interviewed require additional support to do this work.
label: BODY

text: 6    Learn more about the Centre’s use of SDC and overall Quality Assurance (QA) process for data shared on HDX here: https://data.humdata.org/about/
label: BODY

text: hdx-qa-process.
label: BODY

text: 7    The Centre recently adjusted its default threshold of acceptable reidentification risk from 5% to 3%. The exact threshold for a particular dataset is
label: BODY

text: always contextual and is determined together with the organization contributing the dataset.
label: BODY

text: Responsible Curation and Management of Microdata about Refugees
label: BODY

text: Experience from UNHCR
label: BODY

text: UNHCR routinely collects data on refugees and other populations under its mandate. This data is used
label: BODY

text: to assess needs and vulnerabilities, inform programming and better target assistance. Although this
label: BODY

text: data has not traditionally been retained in formats and locations that would make it easily retrievable
label: BODY

text: for future use, UNHCR is now in the process of creating an internal and an external microdata library.
label: BODY

text: By creating these online repositories that will allow public access to microdata for internal and
label: BODY

text: external users, UNHCR aims to enable more extensive use of the data by a variety of stakeholders and
label: BODY

text: prevent duplication in data collection efforts moving forward.
label: BODY

text: Public dissemination of microdata has many potential benefits, but it also comes with potential risks.
label: BODY

text: Dissemination without appropriate disclosure control measures can enable intruders to identify the
label: BODY

text: entities (individuals or households) whose data is being shared, even if direct identifiers like names
label: BODY

text: and addresses have been removed. In accordance with UNHCR’s data protection policy, the identity
label: BODY

text: of persons of concern must be protected and therefore datasets must be properly anonymized before
label: BODY

text: they can be shared. UNHCR data is especially sensitive, as it concerns particularly vulnerable groups
label: BODY

text: of people, whose protection is of the utmost importance.
label: BODY

text: To ensure protection and responsible dissemination of microdata, UNHCR utilizes the sdcMicro app
label: BODY

text: in R to calculate the re-identification risks of such data before they are published. The process is
label: BODY

text: managed by UNHCR’s data curation team, which works together with the data owners to identify key
label: BODY

text: variables, assess the sensitivity of the data, and set an acceptable risk level for a particular dataset.
label: BODY

text: After anonymization, the modified data is compared to the original and assessed for information loss.
label: BODY

text: If the data owner judges that certain modified variables are essential for consumers of the data, the
label: BODY

text: disclosure control methods can be adjusted accordingly. For example, in the case of the
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: AUGUST 2019
label: BODY

text: Opportunities and challenges to incorporating SDC into an organization’s workflow
label: BODY

text: Experience from REACH
label: BODY

text: REACH began exploring the potential of SDC in June 2018, when the HDX team first applied the
label: BODY

text: sdcMicro R package to a dataset that REACH uploaded to the platform. The types of data for which the
label: BODY

text: HDX team have applied SDC for REACH include household surveys and key informant interviews (and
label: BODY

text: associated metadata). REACH has not yet applied SDC directly but are looking into the requirements
label: BODY

text: for doing so.
label: BODY

text: Based on experience to-date, REACH suggests that organizations interested in incorporating SDC into
label: BODY

text: their workflow consider the following questions:
label: BODY

text: •	 Is this the right methodology for your existing microdata management processes?
label: BODY

text: •	 To what extent does application of SDC lower the validity and utility of the data?
label: BODY

text: •	 How does the application of SDC affect transparency?
label: BODY

text: •	 How can you ensure that personnel do not rely too much on the outcomes of an SDC disclosure
label: BODY

text: risk assessment and ensure that they keep thinking critically about potential risks of different
label: BODY

text: data types?
label: BODY

text: REACH has determined that it would be operationally feasible to roll out the technical aspects of SDC
label: BODY

text: relatively easily both at HQ and field level. At HQ this would mean running a script on all datasets
label: BODY

text: produced or published by REACH. At the field level, this would mean getting country teams to use
label: BODY

text: sdcMicro or a similar tool on all datasets produced in country.
label: BODY

text: Beyond the technical aspects of SDC, REACH sees the potential challenge or bottleneck in the
label: BODY

text: manual component of the process whereby staff must decide whether a particular disclosure control
label: BODY

text: technique is appropriate, which variables to remove or otherwise obfuscate and how to interpret and
label: BODY

text: communicate the results of the process. These decisions take time and require an understanding of
label: BODY

text: the context to which the data relates.
label: BODY

text: In the near-term, REACH will continue collaborating with the HDX team to conduct SDC on survey and
label: BODY

text: assessment data before publication on HDX. This experience will enable REACH to determine how
label: BODY

text: best to incorporate SDC into its own workflows at the global and country level in the future.
label: BODY

text: By working with data contributors like REACH (see case study below) to develop a reliable and secure SDC
label: BODY

text: service model, the Centre aims to support responsible sharing of this data and demonstrate the value
label: BODY

text: of more robust techniques for disclosure risk assessment and data anonymization. Exposure to these
label: BODY

text: techniques also helps humanitarian organizations identify tools and methods that they can incorporate
label: BODY

text: into their own data management processes, while contributing to the broader body of knowledge within
label: BODY

text: the sector on how to more responsibly manage and share microdata in humanitarian settings.
label: BODY

text: Standardized Expanded Nutrition Surveys (SENS), the curation team decided not to apply aggregation
label: BODY

text: in age brackets that would normally be applied because these brackets were key to characterizing
label: BODY

text: malnutrition by age in years and months for children. The team maintained the age variable but
label: BODY

text: excluded the date of birth and the survey date. This led to an acceptable risk scenario while keeping
label: BODY

text: the data useful for nutritionists.
label: BODY

text: UNHCR continues to invest in this process by growing its curation team and increasing the technical
label: BODY

text: expertise in anonymization techniques within the organization. Under the current plan, the UNHCR
label: BODY

text: Microdata Library will be fully operational and populated with forced displacement microdata at the
label: BODY

text: end of 2019.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: AUGUST 2019
label: BODY

text: The Centre and its collaborators on this guidance note recommend that organizations invest in the following
label: BODY

text: three areas for successful adoption of SDC:
label: BODY

text: 1. Selecting the right tool
label: HH3

text: There are a variety of tools to conduct SDC available for free online. The Centre and other humanitarian
label: BODY

text: organizations consulted during the Centre’s research currently use sdcMicro. The Centre chose
label: BODY

text: sdcMicro for its scalability and because it is free and open source. Other free and open source tools
label: BODY

text: include μArgus and ARX. In selecting the appropriate tool for conducting SDC, organizations should
label: BODY

text: consider the flexibility of the tool in the selecting key variables, the capacity of the tool to handle large
label: BODY

text: datasets, the built in risk-utility trade off functionality and the ease with which staff would be able to
label: BODY

text: navigate the tool’s user interface.
label: BODY

text: 2. Integrating SDC into existing data management workflows
label: HH3

text: Establishing a process for the application of SDC within existing data management workflows is key
label: BODY

text: to sustainable adoption of the method. SDC requires engagement of staff with different knowledge
label: BODY

text: and skills, including a technical specialist to apply the statistical methods and  a programme specialist
label: BODY

text: with an understanding of the context of the data to determine the acceptable risk-utility balance. A
label: BODY

text: well-organized workflow will help improve efficiency of the process and help prevent misinterpretation
label: BODY

text: of or overreliance on the outcomes of SDC.
label: BODY

text: 3. Improving practice through continuous learning
label: HH3

text: As organizations apply SDC, they will learn about the sensitivity of different key variables, the
label: BODY

text: appropriate risk level to strive for, the acceptable level of information loss and other considerations
label: BODY

text: that must be balanced in the process. Keeping a record of each application of SDC and documenting
label: BODY

text: lessons learned will help refine the process over time. Sharing these insights internally and, as
label: BODY

text: appropriate, with the broader humanitarian community can support more consistent and responsible
label: BODY

text: management of microdata in the sector.
label: BODY

text: As part of its efforts to support more responsible management and sharing of sensitive humanitarian data,
label: BODY

text: the Centre is enhancing its service model8 for conducting SDC. This work includes the introduction of an
label: BODY

text: automated risk detection process for all data shared through HDX, which — when done manually — can
label: BODY

text: take several hours for large spreadsheets. Through this process, a script will run on all data uploaded to the
label: BODY

text: platform to identify microdata and other forms of potentially sensitive data. High-risk data will be sent into
label: BODY

text: a dedicated workflow to be assessed and, if necessary, modified through SDC to reduce re-identification risk
label: BODY

text: before the data is shared more widely.
label: BODY

text: To learn more about the Centre’s work on SDC, contact centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY

text: RECOMMENDATIONS FOR INCREASING THE USE OF SDC IN HUMANITARIAN
label: HH3

label: H4

text: COLLABORATORS: UNHCR AND REACH INITIATIVE.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data (‘the Centre’)together with key partners, is publishing a series of eight
label: BODY

text: guidance notes on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action over the course of 2019 and 2020. The Guidance
label: BODY

text: Note series follows the publication of the OCHA Data Responsibility Guidelines in March 2019. Through
label: BODY

text: the series, the Centre aims to provide additional guidance on specific issues, processes and tools for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility in practice. This series is made possible with the generous support of the Directorate-General for
label: BODY

text: European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (DG ECHO).
label: BODY
